title: How do natural laws relate to the existence of spiritual freedom according to Leibniz, Boutroux, and Kant?
first_phrase: This final section explores the views of Leibniz, Boutroux, and Kant on natural laws and their role in determining human freedom. The author argues that natural determinism is indifferent to the quality and intentionality of phenomena and only explains the consequences that follow, leaving room for human agency. They draw analogies from the world of scientific inventions to understand the vast and varied phenomena that follow the same laws. The previous section highlights the limitations of positivist science and the blurred boundaries between science and magic.

In effetti, è incontestabile che, anche tralasciando dò che è dominio di contingenze storico-sociali (p. es. rivo luzioni, epidemie, correnti di idee, ecc. ), esiste una larga zona, comprendente p. es. i fenomeni sismici, meteorolo gici, ecc. in ordine alla quale la scienza fisica sarà ________________ FRA SCIENZA POSITIVA E MAGIA 319 Materiale protetto da copyright sempre pronta a spiegare il come, cioè quali leggi gene rali questi fenomeni seguono, una volta che siano acca duti; ma, quanto al loro accadere, essa non è in grado di prevederlo e di determinarlo secondo legge.
last_phrase: In conclusion, while science may provide a general understanding of the natural world through its laws and principles, it also acknowledges the limits of its knowledge and the presence of unexplainable factors. Therefore, we must approach scientific findings with a critical mind and recognize that there may be phenomena outside of its realm of explanation.
